3.5 DesignConstraints
3.5.1 CommercialOff-The-ShelfSoftware
3.5.1.1 The dataProcessingAndSecurity, and reportingFunctions of the RLCSapplicationSoftware shall be implemented with commercialOff-The-ShelfSoftware.
3.5.1.2 The dataProcessing, security, and reportingFunctions as well as the server and clientOperatingSystems would preferably use the following:
• Oracle8i for the databaseServer and clients
• HPUX or SolarisServerOperatingSystem (latest version)
• WindowsNT or Linux for the clientOperatingSystem (latest version)
• OS/9 or otherRealTimeOperatingSystem for the controllerOperatingSystem
• CrystalReports, Brio or comparable for reportingPackage
• CCC/Harvest or comparable for changeAndConfigurationManagement.
3.5.2 Security
The RLCS shall incorporateADataBase to store, process, and retrieveAllData necessary to secureTheSystem from unauthorizedUse. The processingCode at the FCU and DCUcontrollers shall be resident in non-volatileMemory.
3.5.2.1 The RLCS shall incorporateADataBase to store, process, and retrieveAllData necessary to secureTheSystem from unauthorizedUse.
3.5.2.2 The applicationSoftwareProcessingCode and applicationSoftwareData such as loginInformation at the FCU and DCUcontrollers shall be resident in non-volatileMemory.
3.5.2.3 The MD5algorithm shall be used to secureApplicationData and software in the controllers and the applicationServer.
3.6 RLCSApplicationSoftwareAttributes
3.6.1 Reliability
3.6.1.1 The RLCS must demonstrateTheAbility to functionContinuously without needing to be reset or rebooted due to an RLCSerror for at least 30 consecutiveDays.
3.6.1.2 ValidChecksumAlgorithms must be employed to checkTheIntegrity of messagesBetweenUnits.
3.6.1.3 The RLCS must be built with redundantCapabilities to ensureUninterruptedOperation. The RLCS will function in a degradedMode in the following manner:
April 21, 2004 Section VID page 38 of 66 Department of Transportation District 11 I-15 RLCS Software Requirements Specification
3.6.1.3.1 If the TMCworkstations or networkServer fails, resulting in lossOfFieldStatus at the TMC, alternateControl shall be at FCUSouth or FCUNorth. The operator shall be able to dialInFromABackUpComputer to either FCUNorth or FCUSouth and openAndCloseTheReversibleLanes.
3.6.1.3.2 If FCUNorth or FCUSouth fails: (FCUControllerFailures or FCU-TSUcommunicationsFailure) LossOfChangeableMessagesSigns and DCUs associated with the failedFCU. AlternateControl at the non-failedFCU (North or South).
3.6.1.3.3 If FCUsNorth and FCUSouth both fail: (FCUControllerFailures or FCUs-TSU and FCU-FCUcommunicationsFailure) LossOfChangeableMessageSigns 1-12 and DCUs 1-5. AlternateControlUnits: DirectControl at DCUs 1-5, and CMS1-12 controlFromCMSCabinets. The operator shall be able to connectALapTopComputer at the DCUs and operateTheDevices or performManualOperation from the MCU. The operator shall also be able to connectALapTop on the CMScabinet and controlTheSigns or performManualOperationOfTheSigns from the cabinet.
3.6.1.3.4 If any DCU1-5 fails: FieldDevices related to the failedDCU. AlternateControlUnit: MCU and manualControl at the fieldDevices.
3.6.1.3.5 If any MCU fails: LossOfFieldDevices. AlternateControlUnit: ManualControl at the fieldDevices related to the failedMCU. The devices can be manuallyControlled/Operated from their cabinets (e.g.: Gates)
3.6.1.4 The currentConfigurationInformation for each processingUnit in the field shall be duplicated in a database at the TMClevel.
3.6.2 Availability
Priority: Must have
The RLCS must be available 24/7, 365 days per year. The normalOperatingMode is Monday through Friday, between 5:00am and 8:00pm, but the system must be functional in order to stay in its closedState after hours. If there is a failure, recoveryTime must be no greater than 10 minutes, and totalYearlyUptime must be at least 99.99% (.01% downtime, or approximately 50 minutes per year).
3.6.3 Maintainability
Priority: Must have
3.6.3.1 The RLCS shall supportRemoteSystemAdministrationAndMaintenance of the system.
3.6.3.2 The RLCS shall utilizeAnOpenArchitecture that is modularAndScaleable. The system will be scaledUp to a maximum of two additionalDCUcontrollers, each with the number of devicesCurrentlyAtDCULocation1, plus four additionalCMS, and
April 21, 2004 Section VID page 39 of 66 Department of Transportation District 11 I-15 RLCS Software Requirements Specification
twenty additionalContactClosures)
3.6.3.3 Wherever possible openSystemsStandards for hardware, software, softwareDevelopmentTools, and communications shall be used.

## 3.2. GSM: Goal Specification and Management Module

This section defines the features provided by the tool for goal specification and management.

### 3.2.1. Functional Requirements

**FR-GSM 1**
Requirement Definition: The system shall allow analysts to add a new goal.
Requirement Specification: The system will allow analysts to enter a new goal into the system as new goals are identified. Following are the necessary elements for each goal:
a. **Goal ID**
b. **Goal Description** (not long)
c. **Taxonomy Classification**

1.  **Protection**
      * **Notice/Awareness**
      * **Choice/Consent**
      * **Security/Integrity**
      * **Access/Participation**
      * **Enforcement/Redress**
2.  **Vulnerability**
      * **Information Monitoring**
      * **Information Aggregation**
      * **Information Storage**
      * **Information Transfer**
      * **Information Collection**
      * **Information Personalization**
      * **Contact**
        d. **Subject Classification**
      * **Business Aggregation**
      * **Browse Pattern/Site Usage**
      * **CC Information**
      * **Children**
      * **Customer Information (CI)**
      * **Contacting Customer**
      * **Contact Institutions**
      * **Cookies/Web bugs**
      * **Customer System Information**
      * **Customer Aggregation**
      * **General Information**
      * **General User Preference**
      * **Identity Theft/Fraud**
      * **Law** (HIPAA, COPPA, GLBA)
      * **Liability/Responsibility**
      * **OPT in /out preferences**
      * **Personal Financial Information (PFI)**
      * **Personal Health Information (PHI)**
      * **Personally Identifiable Information (PII)**
      * **PFI/PHI/PII Usage**
      * **Policies/Procedures**
      * **PP/ToU**
      * **Security Access**
        e. **Goal Actor**
        f. **Policy in which the goal was found**
        g. **Granularity Classification** (Policy or Scenario goal)
        h. **Observable/Unobservable**
        i. **Occurrences**
        j. **Context Information** (for the goal)
        k. **Relevant Legislation** (e.g, HIPAA, COPPA, GLBA)
        Origin: Customer interview (Qingfeng He) 02/06/04
        Priority: 3

## 3.4. FRE: Flesch Readability Module

This section contains requirements that calculate the Flesch Readability Index of policy documents.

### 3.4.1. Functional Requirements

**FR-P3P 5**
Requirement Definition: The system shall provide a way to evaluate the information extracted from the P3P privacy policy against the information extracted from the user’s privacy preferences.
Requirement Specification: The system will provide users an unambiguous way to evaluate the information extracted from the privacy policy against the information extracted from the user’s privacy preferences. During the evaluation, following scenarios need to be dealt with:
* If the data-usage goals information mined from the P3P policy match those from the user's privacy preferences corresponding to both acceptance and rejection of a policy, then a **conflict should be detected** and a notification requiring user's intervention raised.
* If the goals data-usage information mined from the P3P policy match those from the user's privacy preferences corresponding to either accepting or rejecting a policy, the policy should be **accepted or rejected** respectively.
* If the goals data-usage information mined from the P3P policy does not match those from the user’s privacy preferences corresponding to either acceptance or and rejection of a policy, then again a **conflict should be detected** and a notification requiring user’s intervention raised.

## 2.2 WLCore
### 2.2.1 Definition
Synthetically selected part of the OpenWatcomLinker ($OWROOT/bld/wl), performing the basic linking tasks (e.g. relocations), and interacting to ORL. Main files: **obj2supp.c**, **objcalc.c**, **objorl.c**, **objpass1.c**, **objpass2.c**.

### 2.2.2 Description
We are interested mainly in ELF linking. Since ORL is used to read ELF object files, there is an interface to ORL implemented in **objorl.c**. The linker uses other data structures than ORL, so there is another mapping implemented in the mentioned file. Relocations are mapped in the following way:

Constants **FIX_** are defined in the spirit of OMF specification (i.e. FIXUPP records). However, some of these constants implement specific features, e.g. PowerPCRelocations.
Here **ORLRelocSecScan** is ORL-function that iterates through the relocation list, and **DoReloc()** is called to convert each relocation (see above).
Relocation processing is actually implemented in **obj2supp.c**. This file is a key part of the linker. Other important participants of linking process are symbols. Like relocations, ELF symbols (accessible through ORL functions) are converted to the internal symbol structures:

There are many **SYM_** and **ST_** constants describing various symbol properties.
Finally, calculation of segment addresses (during the second pass) is performed in **objcalc.c**. Information produced during this process will be used later for creating an executable file. One can iterate through the groups (i.e. grouped segments) this way:es:

There are some important global variables. In the example above, we see **Groups** is the list of all groups. Variable **DataGroup** specifies the data group, variable **NumGroups** contains the total number of groups. Group entry is defined as:

Here **size** is group size in the file; **totalsize** is group size in the memory (e.g. uninitialized data do not require space in the file).
Another important global variable is **FmtData**. This structure contains fields describing the format and various properties of the output file. For our purposes, the most important fields are **type** and **dll**. For ELF shared objects, the following test evaluates as TRUE: (**FmtData.type** & **MK_ELF**) && **FmtData.dll**.

## 2.3 Load ELF
### 2.3.1 Definition
Part of OpenWatcomLinker ($OWROOT/bld/wl), designed for writing executable files in ELF format. Consists of two files: **loadelf.c** and **loadelf2.c**.

### 2.3.2 Description
Currently, LoadELF is able to create only ELF executable files (shared objects are not supported). Most of the work is performed in **loadelf.c**. The second file, **loadelf2.c**, contains only the routines for creating ELF symbol tables.
The main function is **FiniELFLoadFile()**. The following tasks are performed there:
1. Initialize the ELF header, program headers, and section headers.
2. Write groups (i.e. code and data) to the ELF file (program and section headers are changed during this process; i.e. sections: **.text**, **.data**, and **.bss**).
3. Write relocation section (**.rela.text**).
4. Write DWARF debug information (if needed).
5. Write symbol table (**.symtab**), hash (**.hash**), and strings (**.strtab**).
6. Write section strings (**.shstrtab**).
7. Write section headers.
8. Write DWARF trailer (if needed).
9. Rewind and write the ELF header and program headers.
Task 1 is performed in void **SetHeaders**( **ElfHdr*** **hdr** ). Sections are initialized in void **InitSections**( **ElfHdr*** **hdr**).

The most interesting structure is **i**, where section indexes are specified. This structure is filled in **InitSections()**. So the order of sections is predefined.
Program header is created in **SetHeaders()** as well.
Task 2 is performed in void **WriteELFGroups**( **ElfHdr*** **hdr** ). In this function, group list is iterated (as described in WLCore). For each group, code or data are written to the ELF file, using **WriteGroupLoad()**. The corresponding program headers and sections are filled as well, using **SetGroupHeaders()**. Note that uninitialized data (**.bss**) are processed in the special way.
Relocations are written using void **WriteRelocsSections**( **ElfHdr*** **hdr** ). In this implementation, all relocations are presented with explicit addends (i.e. **SHT_RELA**).
Task 5 is performed by **WriteElfSymTable**( **ElfSymTable*** **tab**, **ElfHdr*** **hdr**, int **hashidx**, int **symtabidx**, int **strtabidx** ). Both symbol table and hash are written in this function. Then string table is written using **WriteSHStrings()**.
Function **WriteSHStrings()** is reused for the next task (i.e. writing section names).
Note that field **curr_off** (from **ElfHdr**) is widely used. This field specifies the current offset in the ELF file. However, it is not updated automatically, e.g. after **WriteLoad()** therefore precise calculations are needed to keep this value up to date.
Functions to write ELF (and other) executable files are located in $OWROOT/bld/wl/c/loadfile.c.

## 2.4 GC386
### 2.4.1 Definition
Code Generator for 32-bit family of x86 CPUs, used by OpenWatcomCCompiler consists of three “layers”:
• General Code Generator, located in $OWROOT/bld/cg.
• Common x86 Code Generator (16/32-bit), located in $OWROOT/bld/cg/intel.
• Specific 32-bit x86 Code Generator, located in $OWROOT/bld/cg/intel/386.

### 2.4.2 Description
Documentation for the CodeGenerator ($OWROOT/bld/cg/doc) covers only the interface to the code generator (i.e. "General Code Generator"). The code generator (back end) interface is a set of procedure calls. These are divided into CodeGeneration (CG), DataGeneration (DG), miscellaneous BackEnd (BE), Frontend supplied (FE), and debuggerinformation (DB) routines.

There is internal machine-independent format (allowing scalability, multiple platforms, and machine independent optimizations). The main parts of these intermediate data (passed to the code generator for particular machine) are "blocks" and "instructions":

This data looks like machine-dependent, since different architectures have different registers. However, this is top-level abstraction. The code generator for particular architecture supplies the corresponding set of registers. Actually there are many register sets (e.g. stack pointer, registers for temporary storage, fixed registers, etc.) The **hw_reg_set** type is able to hold one or more registers (or be empty).
For 32-bit family of x86 processors, the register sets are defined in $OWROOT/cg/intel/386/c/386rgtbl.c. There are many inline functions operating with register sets ($OWROOT/cg/h/cghwreg.h). Most of them implement "set arithmetic": **HW_Asgn**, **HW_CAsgn**, **HW_CEqual**, **HW_COnlyOn**, **HW_COvlap**, **HW_CSubset**, **HW_CTurnOff**, **HW_CTurnOn**, **HW_Equal**, **HW_OnlyOn**, **HW_Ovlap**, **HW_Subset**, **HW_TurnOff**, **HW_TurnOn**.

There are two levels of code generation for x86: middle level and low level (assuming high level is machine-independent).
High level uses instruction and related functions (only some are shown):

At the low level, we generate the actual x86 opcodes (once and for all). Transformation from middle level to low level is performed mainly by **i86enc.c**, **i86enc2.c** ($OWROOT/bld/cg/intel), **i86enc32.c** ($OWROOT/bld/cg/intel/386).

------------------------------29

OMF file is composed of object records. These records contain miscellaneous linking information, e.g.:
**EXTDEF** ExternalNamesDefinitionRecord (imported symbols)
**PUBDEF** PublicNamesDefinitionRecord (exported symbols)
**SEGDEF** SegmentDefinitionRecord (describes a logical segment)
**GRPDEF** GroupDefinitionRecord (segments to be collected together)
**FIXUPP** FixupRecord (relocations)
**BAKPAT** BackpatchRecord (relocations)
**LEDATA** LogicalEnumeratedDataRecord (binary code or data)
Actual writing is performed by void **PutObjRec**( byte **class**, byte ***buff**, uint **len** ) located in **posixio.c**. For example, class of **LEDATA** is either 0xA0 or 0xA1.

---

## 2.5 OWL
### 2.5.1 Definition
Abbreviation of “ObjectWritingLibrary”. Located in $OWROOT/bld/owl.
OWL is designed for writing object files in ELF and COFF formats. We are interested mainly in the ELF (**owelf.c**). However, OWL is not an abstract wrapper (like ORL). But rather a set of data structures and functions, useful for creating object files.

### 2.5.2 Description
OWL is currently used by RISC code generators (AlphaAXP and PowerPC). As mentioned above, OWL is not currently used by CG386.
OWL provides set of useful functions for creating ELF object files. These functions cover sections, symbols, and relocations.

1. Ingest (Getting files into the system)
* The system should take in files from different sources like publishers or CDs.
* It should check for viruses and make sure the files are in the right format.
* It should change files to the correct format if needed (like from JPEG to TIFF).
* It should give each file a unique ID and keep track of different versions.
* It should allow people to accept or reject files after checking them.
* It should generate metadata (extra information about files like title, author, etc.).
* Everything it does should be recorded (audit trail).

2. Archival Storage (Storing files safely for the future)
* It should move and store files properly.
* It should use different types of storage like online or offline storage.
* It should keep the files safe even during changes or updates.
* It should check that files are not corrupted using tools like CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check).
* It should have a backup system in case of disasters like data loss.
* It should be able to give files when someone wants to access them.

3. Data Management (Managing information about the files)
* It should keep all information about files in a database.
* It should allow people to search for and view information about files.
* It should be able to make reports like how many files were added, used, or removed.
* It should allow changes or updates to the database when needed.
4. Administration (Managing the system)
* It should allow staff to make agreements with people who give files.
* It should keep the system running properly and check its performance.
* It should let staff update or remove files if needed.
* It should help decide the rules and plans for how the system works (like what formats are allowed).
* It should check that files follow the rules before accepting them.
* It should be able to send files when people ask for them (based on a schedule or event).

5. Preservation Planning (Making sure files stay usable in the future)
* It should keep track of what users need and how technology is changing.
* It should make plans for how to keep files safe even if technology changes.
* It should test new ways of saving files and suggest updates to the system.
* It should help design file formats and methods for long-term storage.

﻿1. Grid Planning
* Conduct contingency studies to determine required Black Start generation.
* Annually verify Black Start unit count, size, and location.
* Document and maintain cranking paths for generator startup.
* Evaluate generator fuel diversity, voltage/frequency regulation, protection systems.
* Coordinate plans with transmission owners and neighboring authorities.
* Establish contracts with qualified generators (RMR/Interim) annually.

 2. Black Start Generator Testing
* Test each Black Start unit every 5 years or as required.
* Submit test results to CAISO, WECC, or NERC on request.
* Notify CAISO within 24 hrs of test, file report in 14 days.
* Maintain voltage under no/full load, start without external power.
* Comply with startup time limits (30 min - 2.5 hrs depending on type).
* Maintain output for minimum 10 minutes during test.
* Include SCADA/communications in testing.
* Submit market schedule for test energy.

 3. RMR & Interim Unit Testing
* Pass technical and performance tests as required.
* Allow CAISO to initiate surprise tests.
* Provide availability tests via formal request (G-213H form).
* Ramp to test MW before start, hold for 4 hours, ramp down after.
* Submit ambient temperature data post-test.
* Meet 99% MW output threshold or have availability adjusted.

 4. Recordkeeping
* Maintain a database of all Black Start units (name, type, location, test dates).
* Update database annually.
* If a unit fails, submit correction plan and report to CAISO.

 5. Training
* Train grid operators annually on system restoration using:
o Simulations
o CAISO and NERC/WECC protocols
o Black Start unit integration

﻿ General Functional Requirements
1. Simulate final mission-like data
GOG must generate data statistically equivalent to the final mission results without relying on GASS, GIBIS, or ESAC databases.
2. Integrate with Gaia Simulator project
GOG must be integrated with the GaiaSimu and GaiaTools libraries.
3. Support two input modes
GOG must simulate data either from the Universe Model or a user-provided object catalog.
4. Process source-by-source
GOG must perform simulations individually per source.
5. Include noise effects (user-selectable)
GOG must allow users to optionally add noise (instrumental and reduction) during simulation.
6. Adhere to catalog and MDB formats
GOG outputs must follow defined formats from interface control documents.
7. Ensure deterministic outputs
Identical inputs must always produce identical outputs.

 Initialisation Module Requirements
8. Read input source configuration
Must load source data from Universe Model or user catalog.
9. Include Universe model data
Must incorporate Galaxy model, sky background, extinction laws, and DMS model.
10. Include instrument model data
Must configure scanning law, dead time, and noise models.
11. Include reduction model data
Must configure models for instrument bias, background subtraction, FoV contamination, etc.
12. Define output specification
Must allow configuration of output types such as spectra, astrometry, radial velocity, and physical parameters.

 Epoch Parameters Module Requirements
13. Calculate astrometric parameters per transit
Must simulate transit times, field angles, and related errors.
14. Calculate epoch photometry
Must generate CCD and average G, GRP, GBP, GRVS magnitudes.
15. Calculate epoch radial velocity
Must compute velocity including error models.
16. Set epoch flags
Must define flags indicating specific observational states.
17. Set epoch physical parameters
Must generate values like Av, Teff, logg, FeH for each transit.

 Combined Parameters Module Requirements
18. Compute combined astrometry
Must derive parallax, proper motion, covariance matrix, and errors from all transits.
19. Compute combined photometry
Must provide average G, GRP, GBP, GRVS values.
20. Compute mean radial velocity
Must calculate overall average radial velocity.
21. Set final flags
Must assign object-level indicators like variability or binarity.
22. Compute mean physical parameters
Must estimate Teff, Av, logg, FeH from all transit data.

 Spectrum Simulation Module Requirements
23. Simulate spectral data with noise
Must add flux noise, CCD combination noise (RVS), wavelength calibration error, and multi-transit noise for combined data.

Output Module Requirements
24. Output universe catalog data
Must write data according to the universe model interface control document.
25. Output MDB-compliant data
Must generate output in the Main Database format for use by Data Processing Centers.

Instruction Matching
The system must match trading instructions based on:

Price priority

Time priority

If lowest buy price > highest sell price, a match occurs.

Rising/Falling Price Limit
The system must reject trading instructions if prices exceed configured upper or lower limits.

Result Return
The system must return the result of any trading instruction to the client immediately.

Results include full or partial match status.

Outdated Instruction Handling
Any instruction that is not completed within a day must be removed as expired.

Use-case: Buy Stock
User issues a buy instruction.

System saves and attempts to match it by stock ID.

If matched, a trade is executed and data is updated.

Exceptions:

No match found

Trade error

System suspended

Use-case: Sell Stock
User issues a sell instruction.

System saves and matches it by stock ID.

If matched, trade is completed and records updated.

Exceptions:

No match

Trade issue

Suspended operations

Use-case: Cancel Trading Instruction
User submits a cancel request.

System removes the instruction if not executed.

Exceptions:

Instruction already executed

No match found

System down

Use-case: Save Trade Information
System forwards successful trade details to the Security Account Management module.

Exception Handling for saving failures or mismatches.

Use-case: Query Trade Information
External module requests historical trade records.

System retrieves and structures the data for display or web publishing.

PretreatmentOfInstruction
Parse and validate input instructions.

Enforce constraints and freeze funds.

Log activity and forward to instruction manager.

ManagementOfInstruction
Add, cancel, and sort instructions.

Manage instruction lifecycle before match.

ManagementOfDealing
Match trades based on predefined rules.

Log trade outcomes.

Store data and apply commission/tax.

ManagementOfDatabase
Interface for database operations: insert, delete, update for accounts and stocks.

Transaction User Interface must support:

Buy, sell, and query operations

Each with structured parameters like user ID, stock ID, quantity, price, and timestamp

Information Release Module must:

Query the latest trading results for publishing

Input parameters: stock name, filter criteria

Trading Management System must:

Retrieve trade instructions by type (buy/sell)

Submit through a standardized CTS interface

The system shall collect, quality check, and distribute environmental data.

It shall access environmental observations collected by various sensors in the field.

It must be able to access remotely sensed data like satellite or radar imagery.

The system shall compute derived environmental data from raw sensor inputs.

It should receive and integrate roadway weather information from vehicle systems.

The system shall allow access to new and evolving transportation-related weather data.

It must accept environmental data extracted from images (e.g., from CCTV).

The system shall accept surface condition details like “icy”, “wet”, or “snow-covered”.

It must process atmospheric condition details like visibility or cloud cover from images.

It should accept weather hazard alerts with time, location, and type.

The system shall acquire and distribute official alerts like weather warnings from NWS.

It must retrieve environmental data directly from sensor stations, where needed.

The system should minimize delays in acquiring environmental data.

It shall immediately process data once received to reduce overall latency.

It must collect pavement-specific data (e.g., road surface conditions).

It shall accept environmental information from railways and rail vehicles.

The system must accept roadway environmental data from vehicles, including maintenance, transit, and emergency fleets.

It should be capable of receiving weather data from official weather providers.

Continuous quality control must be applied to all environmental data.

The system must assign quality flags to data to indicate reliability or errors.

Data collectors should receive alerts about the quality of their submitted data.

The system must detect data values that fall outside acceptable ranges.

Original raw data should never be altered.

Quality checks must consider the completeness of metadata.

Manual override of automatic quality assessments must be supported.

The system must record how quality control checks were performed.

It should apply different quality rules depending on data type, situation, or location.

Quality checks should use historical patterns and comparisons to nearby data points.

The system must log errors in data submissions.

Sensor equipment information should be retrievable by users.

The system must disseminate data with minimal delays.

It must allow spatial filtering to serve regional or custom-area data.

A short-term data history (e.g., 7 days) must be maintained.

Users must be notified when system changes are made.

No approval should be required to request environmental data.

System administrators should manage user groups and permissions.

The publication of data may be restricted based on the source.

The system shall record system usage statistics and transaction logs.

F-101: The system shall implement quality checking processes as soon as data become available.

F-101B1: The system shall allow schedules for executing quality checking to be configured.

F-151: The system shall record the methods applied during quality checking.

F-151B1: It shall log the specific quality checking methods used for each data set.

F-155: The system shall support implementation of quality rules for each environmental parameter.

F-155B1: It shall allow configuration of these rules.

F-155B2: Administrators shall be able to manage quality rules.

F-161: The system shall support quality rules specific to environmental situations (e.g., storms).

F-161B1: These situation-based rules shall be configurable.

F-163: The system shall support rules specific to observation locations (e.g., different regions).

F-163B1: These location-based rules shall be configurable.

F-171: The system shall allow historical data to be used for quality checking.

F-171B1: Historical datasets shall be configurable as part of the rules.

F-175: The system shall support multiple algorithms for performing quality checks.

F-175B1: Administrators shall be able to configure which algorithms are used.

F-213: The system shall allow access to new types of environmental data.

F-213B1: New data types must be supported through configuration.

F-806: The system shall enable user security group management.

F-806B1: Security group members must be manageable.

F-806B2: A security group for administrators must exist.

F-806B3: A security group for quality managers must exist.

F-811: The system shall restrict data publication based on its source.

F-811B1: It shall store and enforce data sharing restrictions.

F-901: The system shall record statistics about system operations.

F-901B1: These operational statistics must be stored.

F-905: The system shall log data transactions (all inputs and outputs).

F-905B1: Logs must include detailed data transaction records.

H-120: The system shall acquire, process, and disseminate environmental metadata.

H-120B1: Contributor metadata shall be managed.

H-120B2: Collector metadata shall be managed.

H-120B3: Quality checking schedules must be managed.

H-120B4: Environmental data collection schedules must be manageable.

H-120B5: ESS metadata (e.g., station details) must be stored.

I-032: Environmental data and metadata shall be managed according to Clarus data sharing agreements.

I-032B1: Contributor-based data sharing rules must be enforced.

F-100: The interface must support initiating environmental data collection, checking, and dissemination.

F-100C1: Data collection may be triggered on demand.

F-111: Environmental data must include associated quality flags.

F-111C1: Manual flags can be applied to all observations from a specific station.

F-111C2: Manual flags can be applied to selected observations.

F-111C3: Manual flags can be applied over a fixed time range.

F-111C4: Manual flags can be applied over an open-ended future time range.

F-141: Human review and quality assessment override must be possible.

F-141C1: Quality flags can be manually added.

F-141C3: Manual flags can be entered for review purposes.

F-155C1: Quality rules per environmental parameter can be edited via the interface.

F-806C1: Admins shall be able to manage security group members via the UI.

H-120C1 / C2: Admins must acquire and manage environmental metadata via the interface.

I-031: The system must provide a UI for administration.

I-031C1–C4: The UI shall allow management of contributor/collector metadata, quality checking schedules, and data collection schedules.

I-032C1 / C2: The UI must support management of data sharing agreements and user system privileges.

F-100D1–D6: Collector Services shall:

Collect data on a schedule.

Transform raw data into internal format.

Store it in the Qualified Environmental Data Cache.

Convert units to a standard format.

Be triggered on demand or by schedule.

F-200D1: Data submission errors must be detected and logged.

F-201D1: The system must collect real-time, in-situ data from collectors.

F-205D1: It must retrieve remotely sensed data (e.g., satellite/radar).

F-211D1: The system must handle weather data derived from Vehicle Infrastructure Integration (VII) systems.

F-213D1: It must support collection of new observation types as technology evolves.

F-214D1–D2: The system must accept surface/atmospheric conditions derived from images.

F-221D1: It must directly retrieve data from ESS collector systems.

F-222D1: Retrieval schedules must dynamically adjust if expected data is delayed.

F-223D1: Incoming data must be processed immediately on receipt.

F-231D1: Pavement-related data must be collected (e.g., snow, ice, surface condition).

F-241D1–D2: The system must support environmental data from railway systems and in-situ rail ESS.

F-245D1: It must support environmental data collected from rail vehicles.

F-251D1: It must collect data from roadway vehicles.

F-255D1 / F-261D1 / F-271D1 / F-275D1: The system must collect data from:

Maintenance/construction vehicles

Service patrol vehicles

Transit vehicles (buses, ferries)

Emergency vehicles

Support for point-to-point voice calls between fixed and mobile users. 

Enable public emergency calls, e.g., ‘112’ calls. 

Support broadcast calls to predefined user groups (one-way). 

Support group voice calls (many-to-many, one speaker at a time).

Support multi-party calls (up to 6 parties, all can speak). 

Enable display of calling/called party identity. 

Support call priority and pre-emption (higher priority calls override lower ones). 

Enable call hold and call waiting. 

Restrict network access via closed user groups. 

Provide call forwarding, including busy and unconditional modes. 

Allow call barring to/from specific networks or numbers. 

Enable functional addressing and location-dependent addressing. 

Support shunting mode with link assurance tone. 

Enable Railway Emergency Calls. 

<2s for Railway Emergency Calls (audible alert must start). 

<5s for group calls between nearby drivers. 

Achieve above setup times in 95% of cases, and 1.5× the time in 99% of cases. 

Each mobile device (cab radio, general-purpose, operational) must support:

Text messages. 

General data apps (e.g., email, maintenance, remote DB). 

Functional addressing. 

Location-dependent addressing for cab radio. 

Railway emergency calls. 

Make and receive voice calls to/from:

Primary, secondary, power supply controllers. 

Other drivers in the area (group calls). 

Train staff (conductor, catering, etc.). 

Initiate Railway emergency calls, with logging and visual alerts. 

Participate in multi-driver communication within same train. 

Enter/Exit Shunting Mode (tone feedback required). 

Enter/Exit Direct Mode (local radio without network). 

Perform manual network selection, including international roaming behavior. 

Register/Deregister train number, stock number, and functional roles. 

Receive and respond to incoming calls with functional identities displayed. 

Support volume adjustment, language selection, and power cycle behavior. 

Provide visual and audio alert when emergency call is received. 

Automatically send receipt confirmation back to controller. 

Allow driver to join the call automatically based on area. 

Must function in all rail environments (EMC, temperature, shock). 

Maintain functionality up to 500 km/h train speed. 

Battery must support full duty-cycle operation. 

Must not interfere with signaling, relays, or onboard electronics.

Call Waiting (CW) – Notify a user of an incoming call during another ongoing call.

Call Hold (HOLD) – Place a call on hold while initiating or receiving another call.

Multi-Party Service (MPTY) – Enable multiple users to participate in a single call.

Closed User Group (CUG) – Restrict communications to a defined user group.

Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) – Allow use of USSD messages for interactive communication.

Sub-addressing – Allow extended addressing (not standard GSM but listed).

Explicit Call Transfer (ECT) – Transfer a call from one party to another.

Completion of Calls to Busy Subscribers (CCBS) – Notify and complete a call when the recipient becomes available.

User-to-User Signalling (UUS1) – Exchange data between users during call setup.

Functional Addressing – Enable calling users by functional roles (e.g., train driver).

Location Dependent Addressing – Automatically route calls based on train location.

Shunting Mode – Enable communication in a specialized operating mode during train shunting operations.

Multiple Driver Communication – Support communication between multiple drivers.

Emergency Calls – Initiate and prioritize emergency communication.

Automatic Self-Testing on Power-On – Device runs diagnostics using IMSI attach procedure.

Register/Deregister Functional Numbers – Users can link their identity to functional roles using USSD.

Receive Calls Upon Network Connection – Automatically receive calls via MSISDN or group number.

Provide Standard Data Interface – Allow connecting external computers to radios.

Support for GSM and Direct Mode Operation – Enable both standard GSM and direct peer-to-peer modes.

Rechargeable Battery Support – Radio operates for a minimum of 8 hours on one charge.

Battery Change Without Data Loss – Ensure persistence of data during battery replacement.

Car Adapter Compatibility – Allow use of the device in vehicles.

2.2 Functional Requirements Specification
The ELSS must capture all data necessary for recording the fishing activities undertaken by a UK fishing vessel.

The ELSS must output the data as an XML file for transmission to the UK fisheries administrations’ ERS system.

The ELSS data must be validated against the UK XML/XSD before transmission.

The ELSS data must be transmitted at the required times.

Each ELSS data transmission will be acknowledged by a return message.

🔹 2.3 Data Capture Functions
2.3.1 Data Operations
DAT: Capture and deliver formatted data for transmission.

DEL: Deliver deletion request for previously sent data.

COR: Deliver correction request for previously sent data.

RET: Match acknowledgments with original message.

2.3.2 Report Types
Departure (DEP), Fishing Activity (FAR), Relocation (RLC), Transhipment (TRA)

Entry/Exit to Zone (COE/COX), Control Area (GBRCON), Discard (DIS)

Prior Notification (PNO), End of Fishing (EOF), Return to Port (RTP), Landing Declaration (LAN)

🔹 2.4 Capture Functions
ELSS must provide screens for entry of logbook, transhipment, and landing data.

Must use English (UK) localization; all times must be UTC.

Must allow population from other onboard systems (e.g., GPS).

Must allow printing of logbook data using onboard printer.

Must generate protected electronic print files (read-only).

May generate hard copies for:

3rd country waters

Transport documents

Cod/Hake effort reporting

🔹 2.5 Data Transmission
Transmit via email (XML attachment, standardized subject line).

Emails must be PGP encrypted.

File naming conventions based on GBRRN attribute.

2.5.1 Frequency of Transmission
Automatic (can be overridden by master):

Daily by 24:00

After fishing, departure, transhipment, landing

Manual (by vessel master):

Before entering port

At inspection at sea

On request

2.5.2 Data Corrections
Must allow corrections for current trip only, before EOF.

Must re-send full report (not partial).

Corrections must be clearly identifiable in UI.

2.5.3 Data Deletions
Allowed only before EOF report.

Deletions must be identifiable in UI.

2.5.4 Acknowledgement
ELSS must receive and correlate RET messages.

Must display success or errors.

Must alert if no acknowledgment within set time.

2.5.5 Test Transmissions
Test before approval using ERS-provided address.

Test facility must verify comms with ERS system.

🔹 2.6 Specific High-Level Requirements
Must retain logbook and corrections until end of trip.

Software updates must not invalidate conformance.

Must have security:

Username/password for owner.

Owner assigns master accounts.

Log every signed transmission with user ID.

Each ELSS copy must have a unique internal number.

Must be onboard only — not for onshore agents.

Onshore reporting only via ERS website or offline methods.

USE CASES:

Submit Logbook Data: User inputs activity, system formats as XML, encrypts and sends.

Correct Report: User identifies incorrect report, edits it, system re-submits full report.

Delete Report: User selects report to delete, system marks and sends deletion request.

Acknowledge Response: System receives and matches RET with original report, alerts if missing.

Test Submission: User runs test to check ELSS ↔ ERS communication.

Print Report: User prints hardcopy or generates digital protected version.

Manage Users: Owner creates/subsidiary users, assigns credentials and access.

Log Activity: System tracks who did what and when, for audit trail.

The product shall plot the data points in a scientifically correct manner.

The grid axis should be labelled correctly according to the input from the data file.

Data points should be coloured in accordance to the cluster number (contained in the data file).

The product should be able to handle up to 2000 data points.

A single click of the mouse over a data point should bring up the name of the data point.

A double-click of the mouse over the data point should cause the application to display all the data point's details.

The product should allow multiple points to be clicked so that multiple names can be displayed.

The product should allow the grid to be oriented by the user. Rotation, zoom and move functions should be employed.

The user shall be able to rotate the 3D grid using mouse input and see changes reflected in real time.

The user shall be able to select multiple points using mouse and keyboard input.

The system shall accept a tab-delimited data file containing:

A name for each data point

X, Y, Z coordinates

A cluster/group ID (used for color)

A description

Column headers in the first row (for axis labeling)

4.1 General Requirements
4.1.1 The DigitalHome System shall allow a web-ready computer, cell phone or PDA to control a home's temperature, humidity, lights, security, and the state of small appliances.

4.1.2 The communication center of the DH system shall be a DH home web server, through which a user shall be able to monitor and control home devices and systems.

4.1.3 Each DigitalHome shall contain a master control device (the DH Gateway Device) that connects to the home’s broadband Internet connection, and uses wireless communication to send and receive communication between the DigitalHome system and the home devices and systems.

4.1.4 The DigitalHome shall be equipped with various environmental controllers and sensors (temperature controller-sensors: thermostats, humidity controller-sensors: humidistats, contact sensors, security sound and light alarms, and power switches).

4.1.5 Using wireless communication, sensor values can be read and saved in the home database.

4.1.6 Controller values can be sent to controllers to change the DH environment.

4.2 Thermostat Requirements
4.2.1 The DigitalHome programmable thermostat shall allow a user to monitor and control a home’s temperature from any location, using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA.

4.2.1.1 A DH user shall be able to read the temperature at a thermostat position.

4.2.1.2 A DH user shall be able to set the thermostat temperatures to between 60 ° F and 80 ° F, inclusive, at one degree increments.

4.2.2 Up to eight thermostats shall be placed in rooms throughout the home.

4.2.2.1 The thermostats may be controlled individually or collectively, so that temperature can be controlled at different levels in different home spaces.

4.2.2.2 A single thermostat shall be placed in an enclosed space (e.g., a room in the house) for which the air temperature is to be controlled.

4.2.2.3 For each thermostat, up to twenty-four one hour settings per day for every day of the week can be scheduled.

4.2.2.4 If a thermostat device allows a user to make a manual temperature setting, the setting shall remain in effect until the end of the planned or default time period, at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period.

4.2.3 A thermostat unit shall communicate, through wireless signals, with the master control unit.

4.2.4 The system shall support Fahrenheit and Celsius temperature values.

4.2.5 The system shall be compatible with a centralized HVAC (Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning) systems: gas, oil, electricity, solar, or a combination of two or more. The system shall adhere to the standards, policies and procedures of the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air-Conditioning Engineers [ASHRAE 2010].

4.3 Humidistat Requirements
4.3.1 The DigitalHome programmable humidistat shall allow a user to monitor and control a home’s humidity from any location, using a web ready computer, cell phone, or PDA.

4.3.1.1 A DH user shall be able to read the humidity at a humidistat position.

4.3.1.2 A DH user shall be able to set the humidity level for a humidistat, from 30% to 60%, inclusive a 1% increments.

4.3.2 Up to eight humidistats shall be placed in rooms throughout the home.

4.3.2.1 A single humidistat shall be placed in an enclosed space (e.g., a room in the house) for which the humidity is to be controlled.

4.3.2.2 If a humdistat device allows a user to make a manual temperature setting, the setting shall remain in effect until the end of the planned or default time period, at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period.

4.3.2.3 For each humidistat, up to twenty-four one hour settings per day for every day of the week can be scheduled.

4.3.3 A DigitalHome system shall use wireless signals to communicate, through the master control unit, with the humidistats.

4.4 Security System Requirements
4.4.1 The DigitalHome security system consists of contact sensors and a set security alarms.

4.4.1.1 A DigitalHome system shall be able to manage up to fifty door and window contact sensors.

4.4.1.2 A DigitalHome system shall be able to activate both light and sound alarms: one sound alarm and one light alarm subsystem, with multiple lights.

4.4.2 When a security breach occurs and a contact sensor is set OPEN, the alarm system shall be activated.

4.5 Appliance Management Requirements
4.5.1 The DigitalHome programmable Appliance Manager shall provide for management of a home’s small appliances, including lighting units, by allowing a user to turn them on or off as desired.

4.5.2 The Appliance Manager shall be able to manage up to one hundred 115 volt, 10 amp power switches.

4.5.3 The system shall be able to provide information about the state of a power switch (OFF or ON), indicating whether an appliance connected to the power switch is OFF or ON.

4.5.4 The system shall be able to change the state of a power switch (OFF to ON, or ON to OFF), in turn changing the state of an appliance connected to the power switch.

4.5.5 If a user changes the state of power switch device manually, the device shall remain in that state until the end of the planned or default time period, at which time the planned or default setting will be used for the next time period.

4.6 DH Planning and Reporting Requirements
4.6.1 DigitalHome Planner shall provide a user with the capability to direct the system to set various preset home parameters (temperature, humidity, security contacts, and on/off appliance/light status) for certain time periods.

4.6.2 DigitalHome provides a monthly planner.

4.6.2.1 For a given month and year, a user shall be able to create or modify a month plan that specifies for each day, for up to four daily time periods, the environmental parameter settings (temperature, humidity, contact sensors and power switches).

4.6.2.2 A user shall be able to override planned parameter values, through the DH website, or if available, through manual switches on household devices

4.6.3 For a given month and year, in the past two years, DigitalHome shall be able to provide a report on the management and control of the home.

4.6.3.1 The month report shall contain daily average, maximum (with time) and minimum (with time) values of temperature and humidity for each thermostat and humidistat, respectively.

4.6.3.2 The month report shall provide the day and time for which any security breaches occurred, that is, when the security alarms were activated.

4.6.3.3 The month report shall provide a section that indicates the periods of time when the DH System was not in operation.

3.1 View Inventory
The system should provide a categorized view of the entire inventory to the Construction Junction staff.

Starting at the department level, users can navigate into the inventory item categories and sub-categories, all the way down to an individual inventory item.

3.2 Manage Departments
The user should be able to add a new department by clicking the "Add Department" button, entering the data, and having the system validate and add the department to inventory.

The system should support editing and deleting departments, with proper validation and confirmation prompts.

The Department Name and Unique Tag must be unique across the inventory.

3.3 Manage Categories
The user should be able to add, edit, delete, and move inventory categories through the categorized matrix interface.

The Category Name and Unique Tag must be unique across the inventory and follow specific length constraints.

Moving categories must respect matrix space availability and prevent invalid hierarchy loops.

3.4 Manage Attributes and Details
The user should be able to define attributes (e.g., Material, Finish, Color, Features) and details (e.g., Number, Text, Selection) and assign them to departments or categories.

Attribute and Detail names must be unique and can be activated or deactivated as needed.

3.5 Add Item to Inventory
The user should be able to add inventory items through the Receive/Add Item screen by selecting a category and providing required details.

Unique and Stock items are added differently, with unique fields and validation rules.

The system should update QuickBooks POS when an item is added.

3.6 Manage Inventory Items
The user should be able to view, edit, and update inventory item details based on their role and permissions.

Fields should be editable for authorized roles, and the category selection should link back to the matrix view.

3.7 Suggest Item Price
The system should provide pricing suggestions for both unique and stock items based on defined logic.

3.8 View Acquisitions
The system should allow users to view all acquisitions, filter them by date, type, donor, and other attributes, and see acquisition item lists and statuses.

3.9 Receive Acquisition
The system should support receiving acquisitions via donation or purchase, capturing relevant details, and integrating with item addition.

3.10 Sell Item
The system should allow marking an item as sold, record sale details, and integrate with POS.

3.11 Reports
The system should support generating reports for inventory status, changes, acquisitions, and donor-related analytics.

Reports should be customizable based on Construction Junction’s evolving needs.

4.1 Medium Priority Functional Requirements
Website Integration
The system should integrate with Construction Junction’s website and allow, in addition to capacity outlined in later sections, the ability for customers to view and search CJ’s inventory online.
The item search can be done in two ways:

The user may drill down to a particular category using the hierarchical inventory view displayed on the website.

The user may perform a search for items by keyword (basic search) and other parameters such as price, date received and/or discount (advanced search).
The “Contact Us” and “Online Donation Form” website pages should integrate with Salesforce and allow donors to upload images.
The system should also include the implementation of Salesforce.com Ideas on CJ’s “Recycling & Resources” webpage to allow for crowdsourcing the best recycling options for various materials in the Pittsburgh metropolitan area.

E-Blast Flagging
The system should provide the ability to easily flag items for inclusion in e-Blast, both while adding the item to the inventory and after it has been added to inventory (such as by scanning the barcode).
This includes adding one or more photographs of the item to the inventory which can be included in the e-Blast or other marketing material.
The system should verify that a stocking location has been set for the item before it is flagged.
A preview screen should display all items selected for that week’s e-Blast, and those flagged but not selected.
The system should integrate with Vertical Response (or its replacement) for the e-Blast email notifications.

e-Commerce Integration
The system should integrate with the Construction Junction website to allow for online purchases and auctions, automatically adding new items to the e-Commerce site and updating the site when items are sold.
Only items flagged as available for online purchase in the inventory system can be purchased online.
Purchased items should remain visible for 15 days with a “Sold” overlay.

Membership Program
The system should implement a membership program to track customer/donor activity.
Membership cards should be linked to contacts in CRM and QuickBooks POS, enabling quick access to customer information.
The system should allow rewarding frequent donors with in-store credit for reuse, separate from returned merchandise credit.

4.2 Low Priority Functional Requirements
Mobile Handheld Units
The system should allow scanning and updating inventory from a handheld or tablet device, usable by both floor and field crews.
Mobile screens should match workstation functionality, avoiding the need for alternate designs.

Inventory Item Story/History
The system should allow the addition of stories or backstories for special inventory items and print signage containing this information in predefined formats.

Calculate Shipping Weight
The system should extend logistics to calculate donation size/truck capacity and store weight data.
If the actual weight is unknown, the system should use average or preset weights configurable per category.

Donor Ranking/Feedback
The system should allow staff to enter feedback about donors, including location details and ease of collaboration.
Reports should be generated showing donation frequency, value, sale speed, and value retention per donor.

Systems: General
System runs on a fully relational, SQL-based database system. Ability to run SQL queries against any table in the database. Ability to access database as an ODBC source. All data tables and data storage are fully accessible.

The system provides real-time processing. For example: pull lists are up to date at time of viewing or printing; system supports live shelf reading and weeding.

Ability for multiple staff members and patrons to simultaneously access and update patron and item records, including on staff check-in and check-out terminals, on self check-out stations, through SIP2/NCIP2 and similar protocols and APIs, and in OPAC. Depending on assigned privileges, staff can view all patron and item fields; patrons can access only selected fields. Record changes are applied in a reasonable way, with prompts to warn when a record has been changed since it was displayed.

For any patron record or item record, staff can identify where it is in use (location, user, date and time placed).

Support for individual and shared staff login accounts; access to modules is granted by use of "roles" or "privileges" that allow each account to access as many (or as few) modules as needed. Individual logins allow user-level preferences and audit trail.

System documentation is library-specific and follows standard formats for technical documentation. Documentation is specific to the particular version of the software in use at library. Documentation is web-based, indexed, organized by function, and easily searchable.

System upgrades and updates include written guidelines for updating servers and clients. Includes list of new, changed, and removed features.

System provides access to all configuration files.

System provides full access to all log files. Log files can be reviewed without stopping system. Logs can be enabled, disabled, and set to a specific retention threshold.

System provides access to root shell.

Systems: Consoles and Dashboards
System supports creation of custom dashboards that display current and historical data about system performance, record creation and modification, circulation transactions, etc. Administrators can create dashboards and give access to selected users and groups.

System provides full support for SNMP and supports monitoring of system resources, including disk space, CPU load, memory load, system processes, system interfaces and ports. Alert thresholds are configurable. Alerts can be sent via administrative dashboards, email messages, and text messages. Alerts can be sent to unlimited number of recipients via any or all alert methods.

Ability to set thresholds on the length of time records are locked and provide, for all record types, a list of records in sustained use/locked condition. Ability from the same console to unlock one or more records.

System provides dashboard of performance monitoring and management tools. Identification of processes with process ID, owner username, IP address (if applicable), CPU utilization, memory utilization, run time. Runaway processes are identified. System status is represented by visual indicators (e.g. green and red lights).

System provides a server management console including: software shutdown utility, software startup utility, server shutdown utility, server restart utility.

System provides an administrative dashboard displaying: last full and incremental backup; last planned and unplanned system reboot; last software upgrade; current software version; transactions waiting to be processed; size of log-files; current count of records by record type (item, bibliographic, patron etc), database utilization (size, processes running).

System provides a management console displaying workstations running client software; workstation name and IP address; and utilities for managing and killing client sessions.

System provides a circulation dashboard showing key performance indicators such as check-outs per hour, check-ins per hour, holds placed per hour, holds paged per day, etc. Indicators can be limited to a single branch or set to systemwide.

System provides a single console with access to all configuration files. Read and write permission to individual configuration files can be assigned to users and groups.

System provides a dashboard for locating and viewing log files.

System provides a single interface for reviewing and controlling scheduled tasks, including staff-scheduled tasks, automated reports, scheduled imports and exports, software updates, etc.

Ability to access and edit email configuration, including a quick menu of common settings (such as masquerading, log retention, bounce management).

System supports SMTP for email transport.

Systems: Business Rules
System supports restrictions based on business rules, e.g. restrictions on deleting item records that are in checked-out status, or restrictions on deleting bibliographic records with existing holds.

System provides customizable 'Rules of Suppression' that specify whether patrons and staff can view authority, bibliographic, order, and item records in staff and public (OPAC) interfaces. Records may be visible to specific workgroups only; to all staff and patrons at specific locations; or to all staff and all patrons.

System allows creation and modification of requesting rules that determine whether a patron can place a hold on an item. Requesting rules may evaluate patron type, current number of holds, current patron account balance, item type, item status, owning location code, and other criteria. Requesting rules also specify whether staff with specific privileges or roles can override specific criteria.

System allows creation and modification of loan rules that allow or disallow check-out of items, calculate loan periods, and determine renewal limits. Loan rules may evaluate patron type, current number of items checked out, current patron account balance, item type, item status, owning location code, check-out location code, and other criteria. Loan rules also specify whether a specific criteria may be overridden by staff with specific privileges or roles.

Ability to specify default value, data validation, automatic formatting, and required status for any field.

Systems: Data Recovery
System provides capability to perform live incremental and full backups of data and transaction logs. System supports use of third-party backup software such as EMC NetWorker.

System logs data changes (such as record deletions) and provides "undo" functionality. Ideally, system provides revision control.

Ability to cluster servers for failover capability.

Systems: Security
Patron data is secure in all transfers to and from the system.

System administrative staff has full visibility and control of user privileges.

System supports secure protocols, including SFTP, SSL, and SSH. SFTP is supported in both active and passive modes, configurable per vendor.

Systems: Maintenance
MARC bibliographic and authority records can be imported and exported, singly and in batch, all fields or selected fields, to and from vendors including OCLC. Imported records can overlay existing short or full bibliographic records. Imported batches can be maintained and manipulated as selection lists.

System supports an unlimited number of record sets, with the ability to import and export set members in batch. Record sets can be the basis for batch field updates; can be used as a limiting scope for queries; can be used to delete original records with the ability to review prior to deletion, write errors to a log file, and undo one or more deletions.

System provides a dedicated interface for creating new staff accounts. New staff account creation process provides configurable templates for account administrator use; provides granular privileges for account creation, modification, and deletion.

System provides a dedicated interface for creating new patron accounts. Patron account creation process provides configurable templates for staff use; supports field validation and required fields; provides configurable defaults.

System supports scheduling of maintenance tasks, reports, and data exports. Jobs can be scheduled in sequence ("start job B when job A finishes") and can be modified or cancelled at any time prior to starting.

Staff can be given permission to schedule tasks, reports, and data exports. System administration staff can view and manage jobs scheduled by other staff.

System supports administrator-programmable and user-programmable macros and/or keyboard shortcuts. Shortcut keys may be assigned to macros or to text strings. Macros are centrally managed on server, can be imported/exported, and can be restricted by permissions.

Systems: Client Management
Staff and group accounts are independent from workstations; client install should not be tied to a specific location.

Client software installation and updates must be centrally managed, using standard or proprietary network management tools, allowing streaming updates from server. Ability to specify specific clients to be updated. Client software can be managed with VNC and Remote Desktop.

All client configuration files are server based; configurations can be exported and imported between clients.

Systems: Queries and Reports
Ability to fully customize layout and appearance of reports. Ability to display, print, email, or save report to standard formats including CSV and Excel, as well as to customizable formats.

System provides a user-friendly interface for designing queries against all record types. Staff can select fields to query; select values from picklist of possible values; select regular expressions from drop-down menu, and use a full range of Boolean operators. Administrators control staff access to tables and fields.

System administrators can create report templates that are available to front-line staff, and can be run as is or modified.

System provides fine-grained permissions to allow or disallow staff to run specific reports, and/or to run ad hoc reports on specific sets of data.

System reports for each record type: current record number, current number of records, number deleted, and number purged. Record types include patron, bibliographic, item, order, invoice, etc. Access to record numbers is controlled at the user/group level.

Ability to define and select four types of printers: receipt printer, standard printer, label printer, and forms printer. All Windows printers are supported.

Ability to print to a file on the server, ftp, email, or printer from any part of the application. When applicable, the ability to select record fields and control order of fields when printing.

Management Tools: General
The system supports (but does not require) streamlined staff login methods, for example staff member swipes a card to log into a terminal or the staff member logs into a terminal by using his/her individual login and password.

System administrators can create reliable report templates that are available to staff, and can be run as is or modified to the staff person's particular needs. Changes in the templates could be done without comprising the results. The administrator can limit the filters and display fields that can be altered to certify a dependable output.

System provides distinct, fine-grained permission levels limiting who can create and clone reports. All permissions should be easy to administer. System administrators can create shared folders to allow or disallow staff to run specific reports, and/or to run ad hoc reports on specific sets of data.

System provides a user-friendly interface for designing queries against all record types. Staff can select fields to query; select values from picklist of possible values; select regular expressions from drop-down menu, and use a full range of Boolean operators. Administrators control staff access to tables and fields.

The system provides pre-defined reports for consumption by library boards or other consumers. There will be reports providing basic statistics like those required by the Georgia Annual Report and Application for State Aid and activity reports that indicate traffic and volume of use that display statistics on check-outs, check-ins, holds placed, and holds filled.

Transactions are archived in a form that protects patron privacy as defined by State Law, while providing useful demographic statistics.

Examples of periodic reports: bibliographic records with holds; items that have not been checked out in X days; item-level holds; items with invalid item type; in-transit items with outstanding hold; items that have been in-transit for more than X days; items that are the last copy in the system; items with a long call number; missing items; bibliographic records with no item records; patrons with invalid home library.

System provides the query selections along with the results.

Ability to see where your report is in the queue of reports waiting to run.

System must be able to support the reporting definitions as described in Appendix A.

System must be able to support the fine-grained reports requirements as described in Appendix B.

Management Tools: Demographics
The system produces statistics that can be used to understand and predict patron behavior and use of materials.

The system produces useful demographic statistics, including transactions by geographical regions, age ranges, etc. The data used to produce these statistics must be anonymized.

Management Tools: Inventory Control
Ability to report on the volume of material in a given library at any point in time, based on new acquisitions, items on the shelf, and items out in circulation, with the ability to break down volume in categories.

The system provides an interface showing capacity of all branches.

For each genre and format of material, ability to compare the percentage of total circulations, the percentage of the collection, and the percentage of total shelf space that genre/format comprises.

Ability to control inventory of uncataloged material, such as paperback books and children's board books.

System provides a utility for transferring batches of items between branches.

The system provides reports of missing and damaged items per branch.

The system generates a list of items that have been in-transit for more than X days (X configurable), per branch and per system.

The system provides a utility and reports for identifying item records to purge.

Ability to count and track record deletions per location and per system.

Management Tools: Patron Records
Queries and reports can be limited or grouped by various patron characteristics, including: age range, zip code, county of residence, home branch, patron type, and preferred language.

The system generates a list of patrons with no circulation or electronic activity in the last X days (X configurable).

Management Tools: Transaction Records
Transaction history is maintained for X days (X is configurable); monthly and annual aggregate information is maintained indefinitely.

Transactions can be grouped by hour, terminal, branch, and system. Transactions include check-ins, check-outs, fines collected, patron registrations, etc.

The system counts all types of check-in individually and cumulatively.

The system counts all types of check-out individually and cumulatively.

The system counts all hold requests, including how the hold was placed.

The system can generate a report of transactions (holds placed, holds filled, and check-outs) per patron, per library, per selected group of libraries, per system, per county.

Management Tools: Financial Records
The system can generate a report of the value of items in the entire collection or a portion.

All reports and data archiving must comply with standard accounting practice and state, county, and municipal auditing requirements.

Fines, charges, waivers, and ecommerce transactions are attached to patron and item records. System tracks fines waived and payments made per library.

The system provides financial reports including: patron account balances by patron, home library, and system; fines and charges accrued per time period and per type of charge; fines waived per time period and per branch; payments made per time period and per payment method.

The system maintains a ledger of patron payments, including which charges payments are applied to, to facilitate reconciliation.

Security Requirements
0620: The system encrypts data over a direct connection between the web client and the server. Priority 1

0630: The system allows for the backup of the data system to local or remote non-volatile storage systems. Incremental backups should not create outages and full backups do not interfere with user interaction for more than 10 minutes. Priority 1

0640: The system is configurable to e-mail warnings about multiple failed login attempts from the same user. These warnings are sent to the System Administrator. Other security risks of this type are the responsibility of the System Administrator. Priority 3

0650: The system allows only valid users to log into the system. A valid user is one which has not been disabled or deleted and exists on the system. Priority 1

0660: To log onto the system, a user provides their valid username and password. Priority 1

0670: The system uses the configured authentication module. The authentication method is configurable by the System Administrator. Priority 1

0680: The system allows the System Administrator to configure a timeout after which a user is automatically logged out of Mashbot. Priority 1
