The system shall generate unique voucher numbers with barcodes and embed security features.

Vouchers shall include:

Project Code

Group Batch Code

Batch Number

Voucher Number

Security Code

Vouchers must include three tear-off slips for client and partner use across different visit stages.

The system shall enforce validity date checks for voucher usage.

Only authorized users may create vouchers or alter validity dates.

Once created, vouchers cannot be edited or deleted, but may be withheld if necessary.

Minimum voucher creation quantity shall be enforced, configurable by management.

i. Distributor Master Information

System shall store distributor details (name, address, type, status).

Duplicates are warned but allowed with differentiation.

The system shall track and print sales history reports per distributor.

Distributors can be activated or deactivated.

ii. MSIU Sales Team Information

System shall maintain salesperson records including team affiliation.

Sales team structure shall support future expansion.

iii. Distribution Transactions

The system shall record voucher sales from MSIU to distributors.

Voucher numbers and batches are assigned based on available stock.

Auto-generated invoice numbers must be created.

System shall allow backdated sales and validate future-date entries.

i. Voucher Service Provider (VSP) Master

All VSPs must be registered with unique codes and contact details.

Inactivation occurs after multiple claim frauds; reactivation is manual.

Payment terms must be stored:

Mode, frequency, consultation & lab fees.

ii. VSP Staff Master

Each VSP staff member shall have a unique code and role.

Staff types should be selected or created dynamically.

iii. Claim (Treatment Form) Submission

VSPs shall submit treatment forms to the field office.

System shall validate number of forms received.

Receipt documents shall be printed with metadata.

iv. Claim Entry

System shall validate claim forms for completeness.

Rejected or incomplete forms are moved to a quarantine zone.

Mandatory captured fields:

Patient details, voucher number (via barcode), diagnosis, lab tests, drugs, referral info, etc.

Claim amounts are auto-calculated using:

Visit type + service fee + drug costs from master tables.

System shall detect thumbprint mismatches across visits.

Repeated mismatches trigger automatic VSP inactivation.

The system shall track voucher returns from distributors.

Returned vouchers are validated against original distributor records.

Return date cannot exceed current system date.

Feedback is linked via voucher number.

Auto-populated details from system include:

Syndromes treated, lab tests, drug details, treatment success.

User shall manually enter satisfaction ratings and comments.

System shall support generation of:

Clean claims reports

Withheld claims reports

Per-provider treatment summaries

Client demographics and treatment patterns

Treatment errors and documentation issues

Time-trend analytics (monthly, quarterly, half-yearly)

Reports must allow custom filtering and formatting.

Access is governed by User Groups and User Roles.

Permissions include: View, Add, Edit, Delete, Print.

Only system administrators can create new groups or users.

Password matching is required during user creation.

Duplicate usernames or group names are not allowed.

User chooses to “Set up a Weather FDDA Job”.

User may choose a cluster where the job should run on.

User decides what model should be used: MM5 or WRF.

User defines a JOBID.

User determines domains:
• creates own domains (Note: This may only apply to MM5 jobs. From earlier discussions: creating domain files for WRF takes a long time.)
• chooses between a number of pre-defined domains
• submits own TERRAIN files

User defines when a job is to be run and/or what cycle to run. If the cycle time is in the past, then the user is prompted to specify whether the job is a “case study” or “re-run”.

User supplies other job specific information, such as, cycle interval, forecast length and other applicable information.

User can specify whether to write restart files and the frequency of how often they are to be written.

User can choose between predefined sigma-level configurations or supply own sigma-level configuration.

User has the option to specify the number of nodes to use.

User can choose to receive email notification upon start, end and termination of the job.

User chooses between standard or custom IC/BC data sources:
• standard: ETA, AVNFTP (GFS), GFS004
• custom: provide data source (e.g., host:Full_Path_to_Dir)
• For off-line jobs, the user must specify the data source, i.e., location (MetVault or a directory) and time period.

Depending on the choice above, user can provide custom IC/BC pre-processor or choose the standard:
• standard processing
• provide own pre-processing script

User is given the option to run additional pre-processors for the IC/BC data, such as, LDAS or supply own custom pre-processor or skip this option.

User chooses between standard and/or custom obs data sources and processing:
• Standard: WMO, SAMS, MADIS, GTS, RAWS, okmeso, SatWinds, ACARS, etc.
• provide custom obs source1 and custom obs processor1
• provide custom obs source2 and custom obs processor2
• For off-line jobs, the user must specify the data source, i.e., location (MetVault or a directory) and time period.

Depending on the choice of the model different options are given to the user:
• MM5: The domain size and number of nodes for this job was determined earlier. Based on both choices, the user is presented with different MM5-executables to choose from. These executables have been compiled in advanced. The MM will be able to retrieve the compile info about the executables, e.g., domain size, number of nodes, number of sigma levels, etc.
• WRF: User defines model options.

User chooses whether or not to run Final Analysis.

User chooses whether or not to run Prelim. Analysis.

User chooses whether or not run additional processing on the model output.

User can choose to save the model output in MetVault. If 'yes', user must specify what output file is to be sent to the MetVault.

User is given the option to save and submit the job now.

User chooses whether or not to run post-processing. If ‘yes', then s/he will go through the action sequence in 3.4.

User can save the above job configuration. Job configurations can be saved to a file.

User submits the job.

User selects “Set up a new 'post-processing' job”.

User is prompted to supply location and name of the model output file:
• If the model output file will be produced by a running or scheduled FDDA-job, then the user supplies JOBID & cycle time
• If the model output file already exists, then the user supplies its location.

User chooses the type of post-processing:
• Plots (NCL or RIP)
• NAPS
• MDV
• Sites
• MEDOC (1 – 4)
• Stereo
• Verification

For each of the options chosen in 27., the user can supply a custom configuration file (if this is applicable) or use the default configuration file.

User must supply destination location for the output products.

User can specify the number of nodes this job should run on.

User can save this job's setting. Job configurations can be saved to a file.

User submits job.

User selects “Submit a 'By Hand' Job”.

User supplies:
Mandatory:
• job id (GMUAE, GWDPG,...)
• location of the script (host:/full_path_to_script)
• time when to run the script
• estimated time of how long the script will run
• name(s) of executable(s)
• max. runtime for the executable(s)
• number of nodes
• location of output products (such as: host:/dir_path)

Optional:
• frequency of how often the script should run
• job type
• any additional information

User can save the job's settings. Job configurations can be saved to a file.

User submits job.

User can view his/her job in the job queue.

User can receive an email notification when job is started, finished or killed.

User selects ”Submit a job configuration file”.

User supplies file name to load.

User can make changes to the configuration.

User can save the changed configuration.

User submits the job.

User logs on with user id/password.

User chooses to look at his/her previously saved job configurations.

User selects a job. User can change or delete this job configuration.

User changes the job configuration.

User can save the changed job configuration.

User submits job.

User logs on with user id/password.

User chooses to look at all running jobs, all scheduled jobs (the job queue), past jobs or all jobs (running, scheduled, old). User selects one of the four options.

User is presented with a job table.

User can select a job and receive more detailed information.

User can look at a jobs log files.

User can delete his/her jobs from the job queue. A “super user” can delete any job from the job queue.

User can stop his/her running job. A “super user” can stop any running job.

User can re-start his/her job. A “super user” can re-start any job.

R5-44.1: NPAC SMS shall set the status of the Subscription Version to “conflict” when placing it into conflict.

R5-44.2: It shall also record the current date and time as the conflict timestamp.

R5-44.3: A completion message shall be issued to both the New and Old Service Providers

RR5-24: NPAC SMS shall set the status of a Subscription Version to Disconnect Pending upon request with an effective release date.

R5‑65.1: NPAC SMS shall immediately broadcast the disconnect message to Local SMSs if no effective release date is given.

R5-65.6: It shall update the Subscription Version status to sending when messages are sent.

R5‑66.4: Update status based on completion of disconnect broadcast to all Local SMSs or retry exhaustion

R5‑46: Requires Ported TN or Subscription Version ID to identify version for removal from conflict.

R5‑50.1: NPAC SMS shall set the status to pending upon request if the version is in conflict.

RR5-12.1: NPAC SMS shall inform both Service Providers when a Subscription Version is removed from conflict.

RR5-14: Upon resolution, NPAC shall update the conflict resolution timestamp and authorization flags

R5-71.3 to R5-71.11: Various requirements specify cancellation handling depending on the service provider initiating it and the state of the version.

RR5-28.1: Set to cancel upon acknowledgment from the non-originating provider.

RR5-29.1 & RR5-29.2: Notify both providers (Inter/Intra) when status is set to cancel.

RR5-30 & RR5-31: Update cancellation date/time stamp for each provider on acknowledgment

R8-6.1: NPAC SMS shall allow immediate audit request execution.

R8‑10: NPAC SMS shall return the status/result of the audit request.

R8‑17.1 to R8‑17.4: Compare Subscription Versions and perform corrective actions (add, modify, delete TNs).

R8‑19: Record all audit results in the audit log

Split Plugin:
Users must be able to split a PDF document using one of the following methods:
Burst: Split into single pages.
Split every “n” pages.
Split even pages.
Split odd pages.
Split after specified page numbers.
Split at a given size (roughly).
Split by bookmark level.
Users can select the source PDF and must input a password if it is protected.
Users must select a destination folder and choose:
Compression option.
Output PDF version.
Filename pattern using prefix variables like [CURRENTPAGE], [TIMESTAMP], [FILENUMBER], etc.
After setting options, users must click RUN to execute the split.
REQ-1: Only one document can be split at a time.
REQ-2: Compression requires PDF version 1.5 or higher.
REQ-3: Maximum 10 digits for [FILENUMBER].

Merge/Extract Plugin
Users must be able to:
Merge multiple PDFs or parts of them.
Extract sections from a PDF into a new document.
Users must define page selections using expressions like:
“All”
Ranges (e.g., 3-7)
Specific pages or combined syntax (e.g., “2,12-16,17-”).
Users can reorder input files and must provide a password for protected files.
Export file list as XML for use with console concat command.
Must support merge options for PDFs with forms.
REQ-1: Page numbers must be valid (comprehended).
REQ-2: Compression requires PDF version 1.5 or above.
Alternate Mix Plugin
Users can mix two PDFs by alternating pages.
Users can reverse order of first or second document.
Users can set number of pages to take before switching documents.
Must allow setting output path, compression, and version.
REQ-1: Only 2 documents can be mixed at a time.

Rotate Plugin
Users must be able to rotate all pages of selected PDFs (no specific page selection).
Must support clockwise rotation in degrees.
Users can apply rotation to All, Even, or Odd pages.
Output options include destination path, compression, and version.
REQ-1: Compression requires PDF version 1.5 or higher.
REQ-2: [FILENUMBER] prefix max digits is 10.

Visually Reorder Plugin
Must allow users to:
Select and view individual pages as thumbnails.
Reorder by drag & drop or via buttons.
Zoom in/out.
Rotate individual pages left/right.
Delete/undelete pages.
Reverse selected pages.
Preview pages in image viewer.
Output path, compression, version to be selectable.
REQ-1: Compression requires PDF version 1.5 or above.
REQ-2: Only one document can be processed at a time.

Visually Compose Plugin
Must allow importing pages from multiple PDFs to compose a new document.
Must support:
Zooming.
Page preview.
Reorder, delete, rotate, reverse pages.
Final output document should reflect these modifications.
Output destination, compression, and version to be configurable.
Working Environment Plugin
Must allow saving/loading the full plugin state:
Save: Alt + S, Load: Alt + L, GUI buttons, or menu.
REQ-1: Requires an operating system that supports file saving/loading.

Log Panel
Must show feedback about operations using color-coded logs:
Black: DEBUG/INFO.
Blue: WARNING.
Red: ERROR/FATAL.
Users can:
Select/copy text.
Clear log.
Save log to file.
REQ-1: Log panel only works if log level is not OFF in settings.

Settings Panel
Users must be able to:
Change application language.
Select GUI theme/look and feel.
Set log detail level.
Select thumbnail library.
Enable/disable auto-update, alert sounds.
Enable overwrite confirmation.
Set default environment and working directory.
Changes must be saved and take effect after application restart.
REQ-1: Restart application to apply changes.

Functional Requirements
System Feature 1: Browsing areas and objects of the computer system
PeaZip’s users can browse and gain access, in various ways, to every area (e.g. storing units, desktop, users documents etc) of the computer system on which PeaZip runs, as well as to included objects (archives and files).

System Feature 2: Variety of ways of selection of displayed in file manager interface objects
Users are allowed to manage the way of selection of the displayed in file manager interface objects (files and archives).

System Feature 3: Accessibility to main application interfaces and modification of view mode
Users are allowed to instantly access other main application interfaces, specifically create archive interface and extraction interface, as well as changing view mode for objects displayed in file manager interface.

System Feature 4: Computer system management utilities
Users can use, through PeaZip, multiple computer system (both for storage units and the system itself) management tools.

System Feature 5: File management utilities that are not strictly archiving-related
Users can access a group of file management tools that are not strictly archiving-related, including secure file deletion, byte-to-byte comparison, file checking, file split/join, file information display, and hexadecimal preview.

System Feature 6: Archive extraction
Users can use PeaZip for decompressing the contents of a selected compressed archive and extract them in a folder, with support for numerous archive formats.

System Feature 7: Archive creation and update
Users are allowed to compress one or more objects in one or more compressed archive volumes in supported formats and update an archive by adding extra files.

System Feature 8: Support of drag and drop between system and application
Users can drag and drop objects between any computer system space and the application across various interfaces.

System Feature 9: Two-factor authentication (password and optionally keyfile)
PeaZip allows users to encrypt archives during creation or updating using a password and optionally a keyfile. It supports both encryption and decryption.

System Feature 10: Graphic display of currently executed functions
PeaZip offers graphic display of the progress and results of any currently executed function through its graphic wrapper, PeaLauncher.

System Feature 11: Feature Settings
Users are allowed to modify parameters for PeaZip’s features including language, layout, file management settings, and command-line tool behavior to fit their preferences.

Use Cases:

Browse and access system directories and files from various entry points such as the file menu, bookmarks, and history.

Select and manipulate multiple files using advanced selection options (select all, invert, filter by size/date/attributes).

Navigate to archive creation and extraction interfaces or toggle between flat and browse views for better file visibility.

Access OS-level utilities like system cleanup, defragmentation, and performance benchmarking directly from PeaZip.

Execute non-archiving file operations such as secure delete, binary comparison, checksum/hash checks, and view files in hex.

Extract files from compressed archives in multiple supported formats, with options for path, password, and encryption handling.

Create and update archives using different compression formats, split volume options, timestamps, and encryption.

Drag and drop files into the application to initiate actions like adding to an archive or extracting from one.

Encrypt archives using a password and keyfile and decrypt when needed using the correct credentials.

Monitor progress of operations with a GUI wrapper showing real-time status and summary of executed actions.

Adjust PeaZip’s interface and behavior through a settings panel, enabling users to tailor the experience to their needs.

From Stage 2 – VCD Simple Package:

The VCD system enables the economic operator to mandate the contracting authority to access his attestations within the VCD system if the attestations are sufficiently described through context specific data.

The VCD system MUST detect which attestations can be used by this feature (e.g. they have to be sufficiently described through context specific data and structural data of evidence).

The VCD system MUST provide a functionality that enables National VCD Service Providers to store attestations.

A functionality for referencing to attestations MUST be implemented within the VCD system.

The VCD system MUST ensure that a contracting authority is able to request attestations via the provided reference (including time-restrictions).

From Stage 3 – VCD Advanced Package:
6. A VCD system MUST provide functionality to collect and process context specific data for evidence that has to be provided manually or semi-automatically by the issuing body, by the economic operator or any trusted third party.

7. A VCD system MUST provide functionality to collect and process context specific data for evidence that has to be provided automatically by the issuing body.

8. A VCD system MUST provide IT-interfaces to issuing bodies which provide evidences in machine interpretable format.

9. A VCD system MUST provide a user interface to the issuing body to provide context specific data for an evidence in a structured form.

Recompilation Feature Requirements:
10. A VCD system MUST provide a functionality to decompose an existing VCD package.

11. A VCD system MUST provide a functionality to identify outdated or obsolete evidences.

12. A VCD system MUST provide a functionality to retrieve actual instances of outdated evidences.

Use Cases
Create VCD Advanced Package:

This use case contains the necessary steps an economic operator performs to create a new VCD advanced package. This use case is similar to the use case 'Create VCD simple package' of stage 2 but adds the necessary functionality regarding context specific data and merging existing VCD packages into the new VCD advanced package.

Re-Compile VCD Advanced Package:

This use case contains the necessary steps an economic operator performs to re-compile an existing VCD package into a new VCD advanced package. This use case contains the necessary functionality regarding context specific data and merging existing VCD packages into the new VCD advanced package.

Provide VCD Packages of Consortium Members:

In order to merge VCD packages of several economic operators, acting as one economic operator (e.g. a consortium, contractor-subcontractor-relationships) into one VCD package, the economic operator has to be able to provide these VCD packages to the VCD system.

Collect Evidence, Context Specific Data and Structural Evidence Data:

The stage 2-collection process for evidence and structural evidence data has to be extended to include the collection and processing of context specific data.

2.1.1: The system must allow flexible configuration so that new data fields, entity types, and relationship types can be added.

2.1.2: Must support structured data entry for common forms and fields to ensure standardization.

2.1.3: Should support multiple deployment models (e.g., client-server, web-based, disconnected).

2.1.3.1: Disconnected clients must reconnect to synchronize data.

2.1.3.2: OM data should be synchronized across all instances using a shared server.

2.1.4: Should record and store data from remote devices for aggregation.

2.1.5: Should use configurable, domain-specific vocabulary.

2.2.1.1 – 2.2.1.9: Must capture demographic and descriptive data for entities: persons, organizations, locations, animals, objects, conveyances, events, other organisms, and travel history.

2.2.2.2: Must record reason, category, date, agent, location, and status of events.

2.2.2.3 – 2.2.2.4: Must capture and update case definitions.

Chain of custody

2.2.7.1 – 2.2.7.2: Should store or link data about treatment: person, type, dose, date, and contraindications.

2.2.8.1: Adverse reactions to vaccines or treatments may be captured for analysis.

2.2.9.1 – 2.2.9.3: Must log actions by date/time and user for audit trails and cross-jurisdiction communication.

2.3.1.1 – 2.3.1.6: Must support electronic questionnaires, digital signatures, status tracking, and updates.

2.3.2.1 – 2.3.2.5.a: Must allow flexible linking (e.g., person-to-location), link data with case/epi/lab info, and track lineage of specimens.

2.3.3.1 – 2.3.3.5: Must allow bidirectional case-contact tracing, support for multi-case/multi-contact mapping, and generate investigator worklists.

2.4.1 – 2.4.12: The system should:

Support analytical searches, charts, maps, reports.

Generate epi curves and zip code maps.

Print questionnaires and maintain a data warehouse.

Support tools like SAS, Excel, Crystal Reports.

2.5.1 – 2.5.16: Must support:

Bi-directional data exchange with labs, surveillance systems.

Message creation and parsing.

Support for standards like LOINC, SNOMED.

Countermeasure and case message handling.

Import/export in multiple formats (XML, CSV, etc.).

Aggregation and summary reporting to higher authorities.

Vocabulary standards must be used when exchanging data.

2.7.1 – 2.7.4: Must define:

Stakeholder communication protocols.

Synchronization and configuration procedures.

Agent-specific deployment packages.

Systems must protect data and remain operational during disasters or attacks.

Must protect sensitive information against unauthorized access.

1.1: Users shall be able to view data stored in Physical Inventory tables via the GUI.

1.3: Users shall filter structures by ID, district, county, ownership, etc., with access restrictions based on privileges.

1.7: Data shall display in units (e.g., metric/imperial) based on system configuration.

2.1 – 2.8: Users shall browse and filter project data by structure ID, project status, treatment, date, and perform map-based queries.

24.1 – 24.4: System shall support admin overrides, deadlock resolution tools, and secured reports for auditing and admin tracking.

Functional Requirements and Use-Case Statements:

Process science data from the camera and relay it to the Spacecraft Control Unit (SCU) in the form of CCSDS Source Packets

Receive commands from the SCU that establish the current instrument state and camera mode

Transmit detailed housekeeping data to the SCU in the form of CCSDS Source Packets

Receive a time message from the SCU and synchronize the XCP local copy of the spacecraft clock

Control the heaters on the telescope tube and on the thermal baffles

Read the TAM

The FSW may have to provide for small dump packets if going down the RT link, and larger ones if going to the Solid State Recorder (SSR)

Any packet that must be processed by ITOS should not be segmented

The FSW cannot compress any packet that must be recognized and processed by ITOS

Game.Multiple: The system supports multiple games and can load them from an external source.

Game.MultipleOpeningPositions: The system supports multiple opening positions across all games.

Game.TwoPlayerSupport: The system shall support two-player turn-based gaming.

Game.Solitaire: The system supports solitaire gameplay.

Game.Defined: New games can be defined without modifying the source code (e.g., XML or config file).

Game.AutomaticSearch: On startup, the system searches external sources and loads game definitions.

Game.End: All games end on a predefined condition; scores are then shown.

Game.Save: The system saves the game state into a file.

Game.Load: The system loads a previously saved game state from a file.

Game.Help: The system includes a help file with basic guidance and problem resolution.

Game.SaveOpeningPositions: The system saves all defined opening positions and reloads them after restart.

Game.Continue: During a game, AI can take over a player if the user changes the player type.

Game.LoadAI (from Section 3.7.3): The system loads new AI implementations from external files.

Game.AIInterface (from Section 3.7.3): The system provides prompts to help users implement new AIs.

AI: The system must include a random artificial intelligence that chooses legal moves randomly and supports all two-player games.

GUI: The system uses a graphical user interface to display the game and options.

GUI.mouseInput: The game can be played entirely with a mouse.

GUI.keyboardInput: The game can be played entirely with a keyboard.

The system must start with a graphical interface that shows game selection options.

Players must be able to select from multiple triangulation game types (e.g., constructing, transforming, marking).

The system must allow choosing from multiple opening positions per game.

The user must be able to select whether each player is a human or an AI.

The user must be able to switch a player’s type (human ↔ AI) during gameplay.

New AI modules must be loadable without restarting or modifying system code.

Games must be defined separately from source code and loadable at runtime.

Each game must automatically end when its predefined condition is met.

The system must support saving and loading games using menu options.

A help file must be accessible in-game to guide users through common problems and game rules.

Torrent Search (Section 3.1.3)
REQ-1: Torrent search will share the same search bar with the streaming search.

REQ-2: Database of torrent sites can be updated via the internet.

REQ-3: Tick box to include torrent search.

REQ-4: Query retrieves seeds, peers, file size, date posted, and webpage link.

REQ-5: If no results found, display message: “No results were found for this search.”

REQ-6: Results sortable by size/date/alphabetically via column headers.

REQ-7: Page button for user to navigate results.

Video Stream Search (Section 3.2.3)
REQ-1: Streaming search will share the same search bar with the torrent search.

REQ-2: Database of video hosting/linking sites can be updated via the internet.

REQ-3: Tick box to include video host search.

REQ-4: Tick box to include video link search.

REQ-5: Video host queries return full name, length, date posted, video link.

REQ-6: Video link queries return show name, episode name, and page link.

REQ-7: If no results found, display message: “No results were found for this search.”

REQ-8: Results sortable by length/date/alphabetically.

REQ-9: Page button for navigation.

2. Use Case
Torrent Use Cases
User ticks “torrent” checkbox → system queries torrent sites on search.

User enters search term → system sends query to each torrent site, returns:

Seeds, peers, size, posted date, and download page link.

User clicks column header → results sort ascending/descending.

User clicks “Next” → system shows next results page.

Stream Use Cases
User ticks “video host” → queries sites like YouTube.

User ticks “video link” → queries aggregators like surfthechannel.

Search results are split by host/link type in the tab.

User clicks column header → sorts accordingly.

User selects/deselects websites to filter results.

3. User Interface Functional Requirements
Main screen is a single window interface for all operations.

Menu includes:

Search bar, filters (parental control), favorites (to store links).

Result window shows:

Video name, website, size, rating, and user comments.

Sorting by clicking column headers.

Tabs allow switching between search result sets.

Click opens result in the default browser.

4. Performance Requirements
REQ-1: Query time ≤ 5 seconds per website.

REQ-2: Sending hyperlink to browser ≤ 1 second.

REQ-3: Program loads in ≤ 10 seconds.

REQ-4: Filter out torrents with 0 seeds.

REQ-5: Sorting should take < 0.1 seconds.

REQ-6: Display 100 results per page.

REQ-7: Filter out torrents with rating < 1.

5. Other Functional Features
Favorites system for storing video links (implied feature from UI diagram).

Filters:

Parental content control.

Site-based search restriction (user-defined).

Dynamic Database:

Websites for torrent and video search are configurable by developers.

Cross-platform support:

Windows, macOS, Linux compatibility.

Search engine backend:

PHP or similar used to perform queries.

1. Functional Requirements (as-is from document)
Migration Tool
FR 1 – The migration workflow shall provide a clear API to handle migration and default configuration.

FR 2 – The migration API will require only one header file.

FR 3 – A configuration must be provided; errors are thrown otherwise.

FR 4 – User can provide conversion metadata to store in output WARC files.

FR 5 – System can auto-store migration metadata (e.g., OS, ARC size).

FR 6 – System can call external tools/services during migration.

FR 7 – Must use persistent, unique, global identifiers for records.

FR 8 – Default external tool (e.g., ClamAV) for pre-conversion scan.

FR 9 – API should support external tools like JHOVE, DROID.

FR 10 – Migration must support multi-machine deployment.

FR 11 – Logging during migration may be turned on/off anytime.

FR 12 – Software checkpoints (e.g., start-trans, end-trans) must be supported.

FR 13 – Dry-run migration must be supported.

FR 14 – Duplicate detection must identify & report WARC records with the same checksum.

Validation Tool
FR 15 – arc_warc_verify will use stored metadata for validation.

FR 15.1 – Validation must use payload checksum comparisons.

FR 16 – Sampling must be provided for fast validation.

FR 17 – Use Heritrix’s arcreader to double-check conversion.

FR 18 – Round-trip validation must be supported (WARC → ARC → WARC).
 Repackaging Tool
FR 19 – Repackage WARC files by URL filter (regex supported).

FR 20 – Repackage by MIME-Type filter.

FR 21 – Repackage by record size.

FR 22 – Repackage by timestamp filter.

FR 23 – Repackage by any WARC field.

FR 24 – Support pre/post operations per record/file/job.

FR 24.1 – Pre-ops can skip records/files dynamically.

FR 25 – Include user-defined METADATA in each repackaged file.

 Reporting Tool
FR 26 – Reporting tools must generate summaries from WARC files.

FR 27 – Must support export in XML, CSV formats.

 WARC Browser Integration
FR 28 – WARC Browser must display aggregated summaries.

FR 29 – Must show manifest of WARC files and locations.

WARC Comparator (QA Tool)
FR 30 – Must provide a diff tool to compare WARC sets.

FR 31 – Must generate difference graphs.

FR 32 – Must visualize crawl deltas for QA.

Enhanced WARC Browser
FR 33 – Implement server-side rewriting in browser.

FR 34 – Integrate proxy mode.

FR 35 – Integrate full-text search from Search Tools.

 Use Cases
These are described functionally and can be modeled as use cases:

Set up a migration configuration via web UI.

Migrate ARC to WARC using command-line tools.

Validate WARC against original ARC using checksums.

Sample validate large datasets.

Filter and repackage WARC files based on URL, MIME, size, etc.

Generate usage summaries and statistics from WARC collections.

Display WARC file metadata in a web UI.

Perform delta comparisons between crawl sets.

Search WARC files full-text via web or CLI.

Visualize change metrics between crawls (graphical diff).

Perform QA via sampling, deduplication, and logging.

Pause/restart active migration jobs from web console.

View logs and migration progress from a web console.

The system should initialize the graphical user interface during application startup.

It should handle the main event loop to manage user interactions and window events.

The interface must support the creation and display of windows on the screen.

The system should allow dialogs to be created dynamically based on user input or system context.

The GUI should allow adding various controls (buttons, labels, text boxes) to windows and dialogs.

The user should be able to interact with controls, including entering and retrieving text.

Controls must be enabled or disabled based on application state or user permissions.

The system should support showing, hiding, and destroying windows as needed.

Windows should be capable of being maximized, minimized, or restored.

The GUI must support setting or retrieving text within controls and window titles.

Menus should be supported, including adding, enabling, disabling, and removing menu items dynamically.

Toolbars should be created and displayed, and they must be shown or hidden as required.

The system should render basic shapes like rectangles and lines within the window.

The GUI must support drawing and updating text within the interface.

The mouse cursor should change according to application context.

Status messages should be shown in a dedicated status bar.

The interface should support resizing, hiding, and bringing windows to the front.

Scrollbars should be available and should reflect window content and scrolling ranges.

Users should be able to select text, move controls, and view dynamic content updates.

The system should support fonts customization including changing font style and retrieving font details.

The interface must handle multiple windows and dialogs without memory leaks or crashes.

The entire GUI must be responsive and compatible with GTK on Linux systems.

The system should offer support for tooltips, pop-up menus, and user hints.

Text input areas must allow for selection, clearing, and editing operations.

Dialogs should respond to close and resize actions properly.

The interface must ensure that all user actions trigger appropriate updates in the display.

The system must capture and store user information from external tools (e.g., email, web browsers, word processors).

The information shall be stored in a centralized repository as either Entities or Associates.

The system must support different mechanisms for capturing various information types:

Personnel Information:

Use the address book to create Entities under "People".

Allow users to add, edit, delete, and group these entries using a folder-like interface.

Email (Outbound):

Capture emails before dispatch.

Store the message as an Associate linked to recipient Entities.

Email (Inbound):

Capture emails from POP3.

Link to the sender’s Entity after storing content as Associate.

Web Documents:

Allow user to mark the start of a research session.

Automatically store visited sites and link to a new project Entity.

Textual Documents:

Let users manually create links between documents and Entities using a custom GUI.

Store documents in relationship-based directories for later access.

The user must be able to view information hierarchically, based on relationships and categories.

A file-explorer-style GUI should be provided for navigation.

Optionally, this browser may be integrated into Windows Explorer.

Users must be able to archive portions of the store (e.g., to CD-ROM or USB).

The system must leave traces/residues of archived data, showing that content was archived and prompting for media remount if accessed.

The framework must expose an API allowing client processes to:

Create, delete, and modify Entities and relationships.

List and access Entities via file-system-like interfaces.

Execute queries based on defined criteria.

A GUI must allow users to browse information and create/manage relationships between Entities.

The system must protect against malicious scripts and prevent accidental data corruption.

The help system must be clear and non-technical, aimed at casual users.

Integration must support software like:

Microsoft Outlook, Outlook Express, Internet Explorer, Firefox, Opera, Word 2003, etc.

The GUI should be familiar to Windows users, mimicking common interaction patterns.

The system should work on Pentium III (1GHz) machines with 256MB RAM.

It must not consume more than 40MB of memory during operation.
